artist_script:
HostA: People think innovation only comes from Silicon Valley, but actually, Mikhail Lomtadze just won CEO of the Year and an Innovation award in Kyrgyzstan.
HostB: Right, for Kaspi.kz—and their IPO on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange was named Best Deal of the Year too. That’s huge.
HostA: It really is. And the company also got Transformer of the Year for improving user experience, which is, like, core to their mission.
HostB: Yeah, and Lomtadze was quick to credit the team and their clients in his acceptance. He said the awards are really for them.
HostA: Which is such a humble way to frame it, but you can tell it’s genuine. They really focus on surprising customers with useful services.
HostB: And it’s not just a one-off thing—earlier this year, he was also named Best CEO in Deloitte’s survey in Kazakhstan. So it’s a pattern of recognition.
HostA: Exactly. It shows that a tech company can thrive outside the usual hubs, you know? Like, Kyrgyzstan isn’t where people expect this kind of success.
HostB: Totally. It challenges that assumption that you have to be in the U.S. or China to build something globally significant.
HostA: And their focus on day-to-day life improvements—that practical innovation—seems to be what’s resonating.
HostB: For sure. It makes you wonder what they’ll come up with next. They’ve set a high bar.
HostA: Absolutely. And honestly, it’s refreshing to see leadership that emphasizes gratitude and customer inspiration so openly.
HostB: Yeah, it feels less corporate and more… human, which maybe is part of their secret sauce.
HostA: Could be. Either way, it’s a great story for the region and for tech everywhere.
